Award.AwardTitle: EAGER: Collaborative Research: S^2 Lab: Educational Platform and Resource for Smartphone Security

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
Although the smartphone market has grown rapidly in recent years, education remains mostly in the realm of traditional computer designs, even when it comes to security. One of the crucial factors hindering the adoption of smartphone security in the educational domain is the lack of appropriate platform and educational resources. One option is to use an emulator but emulators have no good support for Bluetooth, USB, peripherals, network connected state, battery charge level, and AC charging state; many of which could be integral components of lab exercises. The goal of this project is to develop a smartphone security education framework and to transition to education some of the emerging research areas related to security issues in the smartphone domain.

The project will develop a smartphone security education platform; develop sample educational resources (labs) that can be supported by the platform; and evaluate the efficacy of the developed platform and resources in promoting experiential learning in the domain of smartphone security education. The proposed platform will be a hardware-software integrated system that will enable students to remotely connect to the platform, choose a smartphone security lab exercise supported by the platform and learn by performing the lab activities on real smartphone devices. This project will enable other institutions of higher education to utilize the platform and resources for smartphone security education. The project outcomes will be disseminated via the NSF-funded SEED labs.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The smartphone market has grown rapidly in recent years while the traditional desktop PC market has remained relatively stagnant. Ubiquitous network connectivity and the ever-growing number of apps available facilitates the adoption of this new technology. However, as the popularity grows, so does the security risk. Although this risk is growing rapidly, education to tackle the risk remains mostly in the realm of traditional computer security. Many students graduate with Computer Science (CS) or related degrees without any experience in smartphone security at the operating system or application level. This is greatly due to the difficulty in finding platform and resources for smartphone security education.

The major goal of the project is the development of a smartphone security education platform, sample educational resources (labs) that can be supported by the platform, and evaluate the efficacy of the developed platform and resources in promoting experiential learning in the domain of smartphone security education. The proposed platform (dubbed S2, stands for "smartphone security") is a hardware-software integrated system that enables students to remotely connect to the platform, choose a smartphone security lab exercise supported by the platform and learn by performing the lab activities on real smartphone devices. The platform and resources provide the students with the experiential learning opportunity through a hands-on experience that can inspire creative thinking and the motivation for future research. This is a collaborative project with Cal Poly Pomona.

The project has produced the following outcomes.

* We have developed back-end server software that controls smartphones and tablets to run educational labs and experiments. This server software is capable of connecting to multiple smart devices, install new OSes, libraries, or apps on them, change configurations, and give access to users. Using this software, a student can conduct educational lab exercises or experiments.

* We have developed a web-based front-end user interface that a student can use to control smart devices. This user interface can show a mirror of a smart device's screen and relay user's input such as touch input. Using this user interface, a student can use smart devices even when the devices are physically at a remote location.

* We have designed educational lab exercises. These exercises are entry-level exercises that students with no security background can learn basic security concepts. Some of the exercises are more open-ended so that we can challenge more advanced students.

A live demo of the infrastructure is shown in the following video:

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=S6wbYf05z1M

The video shows the following pieces of the infrastructure:

* Hardware setup: a number of smartphones and tablets connect to a server, which controls the connected devices.

* How the web client works: the web client shows a connected device's screen, which is interatable by a user. Using this interface, a user can use the device just as the user would with a real device.

* A few showcases of the capabilities: we show that it's possible to capture device information, analyze web traffic, and run a sniffer in the background.
